docs.title: Welcome to Graphica
docs.text:
The simplest Python GUI library ever created.

Graphica makes building desktop applications incredibly easy. No complex setup, no confusing APIs - just clean, intuitive Python code that anyone can understand.

docs.title: Why Graphica?
docs.text:
✨ Simple Syntax - Create widgets in one line with intuitive parameters

🚀 Fast Development - Build complete applications in minutes, not hours

📚 Easy to Learn - If you know basic Python, you already know Graphica

🎨 Clean Code - Your GUI code is readable and maintainable

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

# Create a window
app = gui.Window("My App", width=400, height=300)

# Add widgets
gui.Label(app, "Enter your name:", x=20, y=20)
name_input = gui.Input(app, x=20, y=50, width=300)

def greet():
    name = name_input.get()
    gui.alert(f"Hello, {name}!")

gui.Button(app, "Greet", command=greet, x=20, y=90)

# Run the app
app.run()

That's it! Just 13 lines to create a working GUI application.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Window - Create application windows with custom sizes
  • Button - Interactive buttons with click handlers
  • Label - Display text with customizable sizes
  • Input - Single-line text input fields
  • TextArea - Multi-line text editing
  • CheckBox - Toggle checkboxes with state management
  • Utilities - Alert and confirmation dialogs

docs.title: Get Started
docs.text: Ready to build something amazing? Head over to the Installation Guide to get started!

docs.title: Philosophy
docs.text:
Graphica was designed with one goal: make GUI development as simple as possible. We believe that:

  • GUI code should be readable like a story
  • Creating interfaces shouldn't require mastering complex frameworks
  • Simple tasks should require simple code
  • Python beginners should be able to build real applications

docs.title: Button
docs.text: The Button class creates clickable buttons that trigger actions when clicked.

docs.title: Constructor
docs.text: Button(parent, text="Button", command=None, x=10, y=10)

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Parameter Type Default Description parent Window Required The parent window text str "Button" Text displayed on the button command function None Function to call when clicked x int 10 X-coordinate position in pixels y int 10 Y-coordinate position in pixels

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: A Button object.

docs.title: move(x, y)
docs.text:
Move the button to a new position.

button.move(100, 50)

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• x (int): New x-coordinate
  • y (int): New y-coordinate

docs.title: Basic Button
docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Button Demo", width=300, height=200)

def on_click():
    print("Button clicked!")

gui.Button(app, "Click Me", command=on_click, x=100, y=80)

app.run()

docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Alert Demo", width=300, height=200)

docs.title: Multiple Buttons
docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Multiple Buttons", width=400, height=300)

counter = 0
label = gui.Label(app, "Count: 0", x=160, y=50, size=14)

def increment():
    global counter
    counter += 1
    label.set(f"Count: {counter}")

def decrement():
    global counter
    counter -= 1
    label.set(f"Count: {counter}")

def reset():
    global counter
    counter = 0
    label.set(f"Count: {counter}")

gui.Button(app, "Increment", command=increment, x=50, y=100)
gui.Button(app, "Decrement", command=decrement, x=150, y=100)
gui.Button(app, "Reset", command=reset, x=250, y=100)

app.run()

docs.title: Button with Lambda
docs.text:
For simple operations, use lambda functions:

import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Lambda Demo", width=300, height=200)

label = gui.Label(app, "Not clicked", x=100, y=50)

gui.Button(app, "Click", command=lambda: label.set("Clicked!"), x=100, y=100)

app.run()

docs.title: Dynamic Button Movement
docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Moving Button", width=400, height=300)

button = gui.Button(app, "Catch Me!", command=None, x=150, y=100)

import random

def move_button():
    new_x = random.randint(50, 300)
    new_y = random.randint(50, 200)
    button.move(new_x, new_y)

button.widget.configure(command=move_button)

app.run()

docs.title: Button with Confirmation
docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Delete Confirmation", width=400, height=250)

def delete_item():
    if gui.confirm("Are you sure you want to delete?", "Confirm"):
        gui.alert("Item deleted!", "Success")
    else:
        gui.alert("Delete cancelled", "Cancelled")

gui.Button(app, "Delete", command=delete_item, x=150, y=100)

app.run()

docs.title: ✅ Do
docs.text:
• Use clear, action-oriented button text ("Save", "Delete", "Submit")
  • Define command functions before creating buttons
  • Use lambda for simple one-line operations
  • Position buttons logically (e.g., "OK" and "Cancel" together)

docs.title: ❌ Don't
docs.text:
• Use vague text like "Click Here" or "Button"
  • Create buttons without command functions (they'll do nothing)
  • Place buttons outside the window boundaries
  • Make buttons too close together (leave 10-20px spacing)

docs.title: Disable/Enable Pattern
docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Enable/Disable", width=400, height=250)

button = gui.Button(app, "Enabled", command=None, x=150, y=100)

def toggle_state():
    current_state = button.widget['state']
    if current_state == 'normal':
        button.widget.configure(state='disabled', text='Disabled')
    else:
        button.widget.configure(state='normal', text='Enabled')

button.widget.configure(command=toggle_state)

app.run()

docs.title: Submit Form Pattern
docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Form Submit", width=400, height=300)

gui.Label(app, "Name:", x=20, y=20)
name = gui.Input(app, x=20, y=50, width=350)

gui.Label(app, "Email:", x=20, y=90)
email = gui.Input(app, x=20, y=120, width=350)

def submit():
    name_val = name.get()
    email_val = email.get()

    if not name_val or not email_val:
        gui.alert("Please fill all fields!", "Error")
        return

    gui.alert(f"Submitted!\nName: {name_val}\nEmail: {email_val}", "Success")
    name.clear()
    email.clear()

gui.Button(app, "Submit", command=submit, x=150, y=170)

app.run()

docs.title: Window
docs.text: The Window class creates the main application window that holds all your widgets.

docs.title: Constructor
docs.text: Window(title="GUI Window", width=400, height=300)

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Parameter Type Default Description title str "GUI Window" The window title shown in the title bar width int 400 Window width in pixels height int 300 Window height in pixels

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: A Window object that serves as the parent for all widgets.

docs.title: run()
docs.text:
Start the application's event loop. This must be called to display the window and make it interactive.

app.run()

Warning

This method blocks execution. Place it at the end of your script.

docs.title: close()
docs.text:
Programmatically close the window and end the application.

app.close()

docs.title: root
docs.text:
Access the underlying tkinter root window for advanced customization.

app.root.configure(bg='white')  # Change background color

Tip

For most use cases, you won't need to access root directly.

docs.title: Basic Window
docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("My App", width=500, height=400)
app.run()

docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

# Small window

docs.title: Window with Exit Confirmation
docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Confirm Exit", width=400, height=300)

def on_exit():
    if gui.confirm("Are you sure you want to exit?", "Exit"):
        app.close()

gui.Button(app, "Exit", command=on_exit, x=150, y=130)

app.run()

docs.title: Multiple Windows (Not Recommended)
docs.text:
While technically possible, Graphica is designed for single-window applications:

import Graphica as gui

# This works but is not the intended use case
app1 = gui.Window("Window 1", width=300, height=200)
gui.Label(app1, "First Window", x=100, y=80)

# Only the last .run() call will execute
app1.run()

Note

For complex multi-window applications, consider using tkinter directly or another framework.

docs.title: ✅ Do
docs.text:
• Create one window per application
  • Set appropriate dimensions for your content
  • Call run() at the end of your script
  • Use descriptive window titles

docs.title: ❌ Don't
docs.text:
• Create multiple windows in one application
  • Make windows too small (minimum 200x150 recommended)
  • Call run() multiple times
  • Forget to call run() - your window won't appear!

docs.title: Window doesn't appear
docs.text:
Make sure you called app.run() at the end:

app = gui.Window("Test", width=400, height=300)
# Add your widgets here
app.run()  # Don't forget this!

docs.title: Window is too small/large
docs.text:
Adjust the width and height parameters:

# Calculate based on your widgets
app = gui.Window("My App", width=600, height=400)

docs.title: Calculator Example
docs.text: A fully functional calculator built with Graphica demonstrating button handling, state management, and user interaction.

docs.title: Complete Code
docs.text:
"""
Simple Calculator Application
Using the Graphica GUI Library
"""

import Graphica as gui

# Create the main window
app = gui.Window("Simple Calculator", width=350, height=450)

# Title label
gui.Label(app, "Simple Calculator", x=90, y=20, size=18)

# Display area for the calculation
display = gui.TextArea(app, x=25, y=60, width=300, height=60)
display.set("0")

# Global variable to track calculation state
current_value = ""
operator = None
first_number = None

def add_to_display(value):
    """Add a number or decimal to the display"""
    global current_value
    current_text = display.get().strip()

    if current_text == "0" or current_text == "Error":
        current_value = str(value)
    else:
        current_value = current_text + str(value)

    display.set(current_value)

def clear_display():
    """Clear the calculator display"""
    global current_value, operator, first_number
    current_value = ""
    operator = None
    first_number = None
    display.set("0")

def set_operator(op):
    """Set the mathematical operator"""
    global operator, first_number, current_value
    current_text = display.get().strip()

    try:
        first_number = float(current_text)
        operator = op
        current_value = ""
        display.set(f"{first_number} {op}")
    except:
        display.set("Error")

def calculate():
    """Perform the calculation"""
    global first_number, operator, current_value

    if first_number is None or operator is None:
        return

    current_text = display.get().strip()

    # Extract the second number from display
    try:
        parts = current_text.split(operator)
        if len(parts) > 1 and parts[1].strip():
            second_number = float(parts[1].strip())
        else:
            return

        # Perform calculation
        if operator == "+":
            result = first_number + second_number
        elif operator == "-":
            result = first_number - second_number
        elif operator == "*":
            result = first_number * second_number
        elif operator == "/":
            if second_number == 0:
                display.set("Error: Division by zero")
                first_number = None
                operator = None
                return
            result = first_number / second_number

        # Display result
        display.set(str(result))
        first_number = result
        operator = None
        current_value = str(result)
    except:
        display.set("Error")
        first_number = None
        operator = None

# Number buttons - ultra simple syntax!
button_positions = [
    (7, 25, 150), (8, 100, 150), (9, 175, 150),
    (4, 25, 200), (5, 100, 200), (6, 175, 200),
    (1, 25, 250), (2, 100, 250), (3, 175, 250),
    (0, 25, 300)
]

for num, x, y in button_positions:
    gui.Button(app, str(num), command=lambda n=num: add_to_display(n), x=x, y=y)

# Decimal point button
gui.Button(app, ".", command=lambda: add_to_display("."), x=100, y=300)

# Operator buttons
gui.Button(app, "+", command=lambda: set_operator("+"), x=250, y=150)
gui.Button(app, "-", command=lambda: set_operator("-"), x=250, y=200)
gui.Button(app, "*", command=lambda: set_operator("*"), x=250, y=250)
gui.Button(app, "/", command=lambda: set_operator("/"), x=250, y=300)

# Equals button
gui.Button(app, "=", command=calculate, x=175, y=300)

# Clear button
gui.Button(app, "Clear", command=clear_display, x=25, y=360)

# Info label
gui.Label(app, "Created with Graphica GUI Library", x=60, y=415, size=10)

# Run the application
app.run()

docs.title: State Management
docs.text: The calculator maintains three pieces of state: - current_value: The number being typed - operator: The selected operation (+, -, *, /) - first_number: The first operand

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Getting Graphica up and running is incredibly simple!

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.6 or higher
  • tkinter (usually comes pre-installed with Python)

docs.title: Verify tkinter Installation
docs.text:
Graphica uses tkinter, which is included with most Python installations. To verify you have it:

python -m tkinter

If a small window appears, you're good to go! If not, see the troubleshooting section below.

docs.title: Method 1: Download the File
docs.text:
1. Download Graphica.py from the GitHub repository
  2. Place it in your project folder
  3. Import it: import Graphica as gui

That's it! No pip install needed.

docs.title: Method 2: Clone from GitHub
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/graphica.git
cd graphica

Then copy Graphica.py to your project directory.

docs.title: Method 3: Direct Import (Future)
docs.text:
Once published to PyPI, you'll be able to:

pip install graphica

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Create a test file test.py:

import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Test", width=300, height=200)
gui.Label(app, "Graphica works!", x=80, y=80, size=16)
app.run()

Run it:

python test.py

If a window appears with the text "Graphica works!", you're all set! 🎉

docs.title: tkinter Not Found (Linux)
docs.text:
On some Linux distributions, tkinter needs to be installed separately:

Ubuntu/Debian: 

sudo apt-get install python3-tk

Fedora: 

sudo dnf install python3-tkinter

Arch Linux: 

sudo pacman -S tk

docs.title: tkinter Not Found (macOS)
docs.text: tkinter should come with Python on macOS. If it's missing, reinstall Python from python.org.

docs.title: tkinter Not Found (Windows)
docs.text:
When installing Python on Windows, make sure "tcl/tk and IDLE" is checked in the installer.

If you already have Python installed, run the installer again and choose "Modify" to add tkinter.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Let's build your first Graphica application in under 5 minutes!

docs.title: The Basics
docs.text:
Every Graphica app follows this simple pattern:

  1. Create a Window
  2. Add widgets to the window
  3. Run the app

docs.title: Hello World
docs.text:
Create a file called hello.py:

import Graphica as gui

# Step 1: Create a window
app = gui.Window("Hello World", width=400, height=200)

# Step 2: Add a label
gui.Label(app, "Hello, World!", x=150, y=80, size=18)

# Step 3: Run the app
app.run()

Run it: python hello.py

That's it! You've created your first GUI application.

docs.title: Adding Interactivity
docs.text:
Let's make it interactive with a button:

import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Interactive Hello", width=400, height=200)

label = gui.Label(app, "Click the button!", x=130, y=60, size=14)

def on_click():
    label.set("Hello, Graphica! 👋")

gui.Button(app, "Click Me", command=on_click, x=150, y=100)

app.run()

When you click the button, the label text changes!

docs.title: Getting User Input
docs.text:
Now let's get input from the user:

import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Greeter", width=400, height=250)

gui.Label(app, "What's your name?", x=20, y=20, size=12)
name_input = gui.Input(app, x=20, y=50, width=350)

result_label = gui.Label(app, "", x=20, y=120, size=14)

def greet():
    name = name_input.get()
    if name:
        result_label.set(f"Nice to meet you, {name}!")
        gui.alert(f"Hello, {name}!", "Greeting")
    else:
        gui.alert("Please enter your name!", "Oops")

gui.Button(app, "Greet Me", command=greet, x=20, y=85)

app.run()

This app: - Gets text from an Input widget - Updates a Label based on the input - Shows an alert dialog

docs.title: 1. Parent Parameter
docs.text:
Every widget needs to know which window it belongs to. That's the first parameter:

gui.Button(app, ...)  # app is the parent window

docs.title: 2. Positioning
docs.text:
Widgets are positioned with x and y coordinates (in pixels):

gui.Label(app, "Top-left", x=10, y=10)
gui.Label(app, "Lower-right", x=300, y=200)

docs.title: 3. Event Handlers
docs.text:
Buttons need functions to call when clicked:

def my_function():
    print("Button clicked!")

gui.Button(app, "Click", command=my_function, x=10, y=10)

docs.title: 4. Getting and Setting Values
docs.text:
Most widgets have .get() and .set() methods:

# Get value
text = my_input.get()

# Set value
my_label.set("New text")

docs.title: Pattern: Form with Validation
docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Login Form", width=400, height=300)

gui.Label(app, "Username:", x=20, y=20)
username = gui.Input(app, x=20, y=50, width=350)

gui.Label(app, "Password:", x=20, y=90)
password = gui.Input(app, x=20, y=120, width=350)

def login():
    user = username.get()
    pwd = password.get()

    if not user or not pwd:
        gui.alert("Please fill in all fields!", "Error")
        return

    gui.alert(f"Welcome, {user}!", "Success")

gui.Button(app, "Login", command=login, x=20, y=160)

app.run()

docs.title: Pattern: Counter App
docs.text:
import Graphica as gui

app = gui.Window("Counter", width=300, height=200)

count = 0
count_label = gui.Label(app, "Count: 0", x=110, y=50, size=16)

def increment():
    global count
    count += 1
    count_label.set(f"Count: {count}")

def reset():
    global count
    count = 0
    count_label.set(f"Count: {count}")

gui.Button(app, "Increment", command=increment, x=50, y=100)
gui.Button(app, "Reset", command=reset, x=150, y=100)

app.run()
